conclusion: Analyzing the problem to determine the width of the base through which light passes.

Understanding the problem: semicircular glass brick with radius R, light rays enter at angle (π-γ), critical angle for total internal reflection is γ, find width of base section through which light exits.
Point O is the center of the semicircle, points M and N mark the ends of the semicircular base, point E appears important.
Light rays enter at angle (π-γ) relative to the horizontal base, some rays pass through the curved surface, critical ray is tangent to the curved surface at point N.

The critical ray defines the rightmost boundary of where light can exit, enters at angle (π-γ) at point E, becomes tangent to the curved surface at point N, angle of incidence equals critical angle γ at N.
For a ray to be tangent to the circle at point N, it must be perpendicular to the radius ON.
Coordinate system: O at origin, base along x-axis, O at (0,0), N at (R,0), curved surface described by x² + y² = R².
Ray tangent at N must pass through E on x-axis, make angle (π-γ) with horizontal, be perpendicular to radius ON at N.
At N, normal to circle is vertical, ray must make angle γ with this normal, ray at N makes angle (π/2-γ) with horizontal.
Ray must have entered at angle (π-γ) relative to horizontal, E is on x-axis, line EN makes angle (π-γ) with horizontal.
In triangle ONE: angle at O is γ, ON = R, therefore OE = R/cos(γ).
Width of light passage is distance ME, where M is at x = -R, Width = OE - OM = OE + R = R(1 + sec(γ)).
Final answer: Width of portion of base through which light passes is R(1 + sec(γ)).
